translation.en: [narrator] May, 1940.
Britain's darkest hour.
Military failure in Norway
has led to the fall of the prime minister, Neville Chamberlain.
translation.ko: 노르웨이에서의 군사적 실패는 네빌 체임벌린 수상의 몰락으로 이어졌다

translation.en: The House of Commons has insisted that Winston Churchill take over.
But Churchill has many enemies,
including members of his own Conservative Party
and the Foreign Office,
who want Britain to make peace with Adolf Hitler.
translation.ko: 아돌프 히틀러와 손잡기를 원하는 외무부까지 적이 많다

translation.en: One of Churchill's greatest challenges was undoubtedly
translation.ko: 처칠의 가장 큰 난관은 의심할 여지 없이

translation.en: encouraging the War Cabinet to keep fighting.
translation.ko: 계속 싸우도록 전시 내각을 독려하는 것이었죠

translation.en: [narrator] On the same day that Churchill becomes prime minister,
Germany invades France.
The British Expeditionary Force is sent to help the French.
translation.ko: 프랑스를 돕기 위해 영국 원정군을 파병하지만

translation.en: But Churchill worries the French lack the will to fight.
translation.ko: 처칠의 걱정은 전투 의지가 부족한 프랑스였다

translation.en: If France surrenders and the Expeditionary Force is captured,
many Americans believe that Britain will be finished.
translation.ko: 미국인 대다수는 영국이 끝났다고 여길 것이고

translation.en: Without American support,
translation.ko: 미국의 지원 없이는 히틀러의 '천 년 제국'이

translation.en: Hitler's 1,000-Year Reich will reign supreme over Europe.
translation.ko: 미국의 지원 없이는 히틀러의 '천 년 제국'이 유럽을 장악할 것이다

translation.en: [Levine] So, the war would've been over for Britain,
and we probably would be living in a world so different today
translation.ko: 우리는 오늘날과 몹시 다른 세상에 살고 있겠죠

translation.en: we wouldn't even recognize it.
[narrator] As the French Army falls back,
the British are cut off and surrounded
at the port of Dunkirk.
All is lost.
If the British Expeditionary Force would not pull back,
they would either be captured or slaughtered.
And that would have been the end of the war.
[narrator] This is the incredible story of how Churchill fought on against Hitler
translation.ko: 이것은 처칠이 어떻게 히틀러와 싸워 연합국과 함께

translation.en: and so continued with the Allies to victory.
[narrator] On the 1st of September, 1939,
Germany invades Poland.
-[engine whining] -Britain is at war.
The government responds by sending the British Expeditionary Force,
the BEF, to France.
[announcer] And now, the first pictures of the embarkation of the BEF.
Never before has an army set out from the front
translation.ko: 이보다 더 큰 대의를 위해 군대가 전선으로 출정한 적은 없었습니다

translation.en: to fight for a more just cause.
Never before have men been more determined to win.
translation.ko: 이보다 더 승리의 결의를 다진 적은 없었습니다

translation.en: [narrator] More than 152,000 soldiers set sail to join their French counterparts
translation.ko: 152,000명이 넘는 군인이 프랑스군과 합류하기 위해 프랑스와 벨기에 국경으로 항해를 시작한다

translation.en: on the Franco-Belgian border.
Once there, they dig in,
and wait for the Germans to attack.
And they're waiting for something to happen.
Although they knew it was going to start, waiting made them really complacent.
translation.ko: 곧 시작될 걸 알았지만 기다리는 동안 안일해졌어요

translation.en: And still, they go on waiting.
Already by this stage, the, uh, war was being called the Phoney War.
Um, some called it the Bore War because it was boring.
So they need to be kept busy. There's training going on.
People are going back for Christmas, going back on leave.
[Levine] You know, there was a lot of football played. Um…
It could be, you know, entertainments,
uh, where people come and-- and put on acts and put on shows.
translation.ko: 사람들이 와서 연극도 하고 공연도 했어요

translation.en: So you have this ridiculous situation where everyone is wandering around,
going, "I thought we were at war, but no one seems to be fighting anything."
translation.ko: '전쟁 중인 줄 알았는데 아무도 안 싸우네'

translation.en: [narrator] But war is coming.
By January 1940,
German generals have formulated a plan of attack on Western Europe.
translation.ko: 독일의 장군들은 서유럽 공격 계획을 수립했지만

translation.en: But Hitler suddenly stalls the invasion,
forcing the Allies to continue to wait.
There is a disagreement between Hitler and his generals
translation.ko: 프랑스 공격 방법에 관해 히틀러와 장성들 간에

translation.en: about how best to attack France.
The maverick General Heinz Guderian
strongly advocates sending tanks through the Ardennes,
translation.ko: 아르덴을 통해 탱크를 보낼 것을 강력히 주장한다

translation.en: a densely forested and hilly region
made up of a narrow, winding network of roads
thought to be impassable for tanks.
translation.ko: 탱크가 지나갈 수 없는 지역으로 여겨지지만

translation.en: Once through, the tanks would rush to the channel,
cutting the British Army off from the French.
But it's too radical for the German High Command,
translation.ko: 하지만 너무 급진적이라 독일 최고 사령부는

translation.en: who reject the plan.
Until on the 10th of January,
a German plane carrying a military officer is flying to Cologne.
translation.ko: 독일 비행기 한 대가 군 장교를 태우고 쾰른을 향한다

translation.en: It crash-lands in a field outside the Belgian town of Mechelen.
translation.ko: 비행기는 벨기에 메헬런 외곽 들판에 불시착한다

translation.en: On the plane are top secret documents
for Hitler's plan for the invasion of Western Europe.
The secret plans, which are now in the hands of the Allies,
translation.ko: 이제 연합국 손에 들어간 그 극비 계획은

translation.en: reveal the Germans will invade Holland and Belgium from the north
translation.ko: 독일군이 북쪽에서 네덜란드와 벨기에를 침공한 뒤

translation.en: before sweeping into France.
[David] Hitler's immediate reaction to discovering the plans for the invasion of France
translation.ko: 프랑스 침공 계획이 발각됐다는 사실을 알게 된 히틀러의

translation.en: had been discovered would have been one of absolute fury.
As a result, he went back to what was a much riskier plan
translation.ko: 그 결과로 그는 군 지휘관들이 처음에 거부했던

translation.en: that the, uh, Army commanders had rejected at first,
which is going through the Ardennes Forest and attacking the French at their weakest.
translation.ko: 아르덴 숲을 통과하여 프랑스군의 약점을 공격하는 거죠

translation.en: [Levine] They go over to something which is much more audacious, much more risky,
translation.ko: 훨씬 더 대담하고 훨씬 더 위험한 계획에 뛰어듭니다

translation.en: but which absolutely sets the scene for the war that's coming.
translation.ko: 앞으로 다가올 전쟁의 분위기는 그렇게 조성되죠

translation.en: [narrator] On the 10th of May, 1940,
the Germans unleash their forces on Western Europe.
[David] The assumption among the Allies is the attack is bound to come through Belgium,
translation.ko: 연합국은 벨기에를 통해 공격하리라 추측했기 때문에

translation.en: and that's why the Allies had put the cream of their forces,
both the French and the British Armies, on the border with Belgium.
So the main thrust looks like it's coming through the low countries,
translation.ko: 주력 부대가 저지대 국가들을 통해 오는 것 같지만

translation.en: but in actual fact, the main thrust is going through the Ardennes.
[David] And frankly, to the French and the British, they must've seen the Ardennes in particular
as an impassible object for tanks, for armored columns.
translation.ko: 탱크나 무장 종대가 통과하기 불가능했을 겁니다

translation.en: You know, logistically, how could you really move an army through that location?
And what the Germans did very cleverly is not just come through the Ardennes,
translation.ko: 독일군이 정말 영리했던 것은 아르덴을 통과해

translation.en: which was the sneak surprise attack,
translation.ko: 기습 공격을 하는 데 그치지 않고

translation.en: but they also advanced troops into Belgium itself.
In other words, they called the, uh, Allies' bluff, and the Allies took the bait.
translation.ko: 다시 말해 연합국의 허세를 노렸고 연합국은 그 미끼를 물었어요

translation.en: [narrator] The Germans pummeled through the seemingly impassable Ardennes,
translation.ko: 독일군은 불가능해 보이는 아르덴을 뚫고 나아가며

translation.en: using a technique never seen before on the battlefield.
Blitzkrieg, a rapid thrust towards an enemy's weak spot
translation.ko: 전격전, 적의 약점을 노리는 빠른 돌격으로

translation.en: using an onslaught of sheer power.
Fast tanks, mobile infantry,
and overwhelming air support.
This was the first, you know, real use of, you know, armored blitzkrieg
translation.ko: 세계 역사상 처음으로 기갑 부대의 전격전이

translation.en: in-- in world history.
The Germans called it Bewegungskrieg, the war of movement,
meaning you hit him hard as quickly as you can
and you just smash through.
You annihilate the enemy so they can't kind of collect themselves.
So, what does this do? It creates panic.
The material effect of blitzkrieg
is to open up, uh, an enemy force to a real danger.
The moral effect is to create complete dislocation on the part of your enemy.
translation.ko: 정신적인 효과는 적을 완전히 혼란에 빠지게 하는 겁니다

translation.en: It's almost like a conjuring trick.
[narrator] The architect of the plan, General Heinz Guderian,
translation.ko: 공격 계획의 설계자인 하인츠 구데리안 장군은

translation.en: leads the German Panzer Divisions through the Ardennes.
translation.ko: 독일 기갑 사단을 이끌고 아르덴을 통과한다

translation.en: General Guderian had a very simple motto that doesn't translate into English,
translation.ko: 구데리안의 좌우명은 단순했어요 영어로는 번역이 안 되지만

translation.en: but it basically means "Use the big guns."
"Don't do anything piecemeal."
He was impulsive,
and he was a great expert on tank warfare.
[narrator] Guderian and his divisions worked closely with the Luftwaffe
translation.ko: 구데리안과 그의 부대는 루프트바페와 긴밀히 협력하며

translation.en: to smash through the Ardennes,
cross the Meuse River, and overrun the Allies,
reaching Northern France in just a matter of days.
translation.ko: 단 며칠 만에 프랑스 북부에 도착한다

translation.en: The speed of the German advance and the distance covered
has never been witnessed ever before.
And both British and the French, they're just so stunned by this.
They've been pushed back into this corridor in Northern France and Belgium.
translation.ko: 프랑스 북부와 벨기에 사이 종주 지대까지 밀려났습니다

translation.en: And this is just absolutely exhausting.
You're not getting enough sleep, you're being shot at,
translation.ko: 잠도 제대로 못 자고, 총에 맞고

translation.en: you know things aren't going well because you're falling back.
translation.ko: 상황이 좋지 않다는 걸 압니다 후퇴하고 있으니까요

translation.en: You know, morale is not good.
[narrator] Guderian's tank divisions split the British and French forces
translation.ko: 구데리안의 탱크 사단은 영국군과 프랑스군을 갈라놓고

translation.en: as Hitler's men pushed them towards the coast in their thousands.
translation.ko: 히틀러의 부하들은 수천 명을 해안으로 밀어붙인다

translation.en: [announcer] The man to beat Hitler is Winston Churchill.
The country rallies solidly and resolutely
to the task of defeating the most sinister madman
that ever aspired to world conquering.
[narrator] Meanwhile in England, the country's new prime minister, Winston Churchill,
translation.ko: 한편 영국에서 신임 수상 윈스턴 처칠은

translation.en: -receives shocking news. -[ominous music playing]
He gets a phone call from Reynaud, the French prime minister,
on the 15th of May, in which he says, "The battle is lost."
This is five days into the fighting against the Germans.
The German Army spent four years trying to do this in the First World War.
translation.ko: 독일군이 여기까지 오는데 세계 1차 대전엔 4년이 걸렸었는데

translation.en: And in five days of this new war, the battle is lost.
translation.ko: 새로운 전쟁에서는 5일 만이죠 전투에서 패배한 겁니다

translation.en: [narrator] Having replaced Neville Chamberlain just a week earlier,
translation.ko: 불과 일주일 전 네빌 체임벌린의 후임으로

translation.en: Churchill's appointment as prime minister
could not have come at a worse time.
Many are skeptical of his ability to cope.
translation.ko: 그의 대처 능력에 많은 이가 회의적이다

translation.en: A lot of members of the government thought Churchill was far too risky a choice.
translation.ko: 정부 구성원 상당수는 처칠을 너무 위험한 선택이라고 생각했죠

translation.en: He'd made mistake after mistake in his life.
When one looked at his First World War record,
translation.ko: 세계 1차 대전 당시 그의 행적 보면

translation.en: there were many blemishes, and, uh-- and as a result, they really did fear
translation.ko: 흠이 많았거든요 그래서 처칠이 책임을 맡자

translation.en: that, um, Churchill in charge was going to be like a bull in a china shop.
[David] Churchill was not trusted.
He was a man who was perceived to have moved ground many times, politically.
translation.ko: 정치적 기반을 여러 번 옮긴 사람이었습니다

translation.en: Um, you know, was he the right man for the right time?
translation.ko: 그가 그 시대에 맞는 적절한 사람이었을까요?

translation.en: [Wawro] But Churchill's a fighter. If you're gonna fight, you need Churchill.
translation.ko: 하지만 처칠은 투사입니다 싸우려면 처칠이 필요하죠

translation.en: Churchill is somebody who made no secret of his contempt for Hitler,
translation.ko: 처칠은 히틀러에 대한 경멸도 저항하겠다는 결심도

translation.en: no secret of his determination to resist.
And he was a brilliant orator.
Here was somebody that could really speak to the British people
translation.ko: 영국 국민과 소통할 수 있는 사람

translation.en: and encourage them to resist.
[narrator] With the looming crisis for the British forces in France,
Churchill's first speech to Parliament as prime minister is ominous.
translation.ko: 수상이 된 처칠의 첫 의회 연설은 암울함이 감돈다

translation.en: [Churchill] We have before us many, many long months of struggle and of suffering.
translation.ko: 우리는 길고 긴 투쟁과 고통의 시간을 앞두고 있습니다

translation.en: You ask, "What is our aim?"
I can answer in one word, victory.
translation.ko: 저는 한 마디로 답할 수 있습니다, 승리!

translation.en: Victory at all costs.
[narrator] But the stirring rhetoric belies a stark reality.
translation.ko: 그러나 그 감동적인 미사여구는 엄연한 현실을 속인다

translation.en: In France, British forces are facing annihilation
trying to halt the German advance.
Alongside the French,
they launch a counterattack at the city of Arras.
That is the last-ditch attempt to try and kind of reverse things.
But they don't break through, you know, it is just not a big enough thrust.
translation.ko: 하지만 성공하지 못해요 그럴 만한 추진력이 없어요

translation.en: With that failure, it's all over.
There can be no reverses now.
This point onwards, it's just a matter of damage limitation.
translation.ko: 이 시점부터는 피해를 줄이는 게 관건이죠

translation.en: [narrator] With Allied casualties and surrenders reaching well over half a million,
translation.ko: 연합군의 사상자와 투항자가 50만 명을 훨씬 넘어선 채

translation.en: the British Expeditionary Force is becoming encircled by the Germans,
and have their backs against the coast.
You've got Belgium collapsing on the northern flank,
you've got the Germans pressing from the east,
you've got them pressing from the south, they're in this tiny little bubble.
translation.ko: 남쪽에서도 독일군이 이 좁은 지역을 압박하고 있죠

translation.en: And everyone's going, "This is an absolute nightmare."
[Wawro] The French were floundering. Um…
Morale was poor.
French Army units were collapsing in the face of these German attacks.
translation.ko: 프랑스 군대는 독일군의 공격에 무너지고 있었고

translation.en: And the British saw themselves basically shackled to a corpse.
translation.ko: 영국군은 자신들을 족쇄가 채워진 시체로 봤어요

translation.en: [narrator] As the German onslaught continues to overwhelm the Allies,
Churchill flies to Paris to meet with Prime Minister Paul Reynaud
translation.ko: 처칠은 파리로 가서 폴 레노 수상과

translation.en: and the French High Command.
The reason he's doing that is so that he can try and get the French War Committee
translation.ko: 그렇게 한 이유는 프랑스 전쟁 위원회를 설득해

translation.en: to try and kind of stiffen their resolve.
"Come on, keep going. There's gotta be a solution to this."
"Don't be defeatists. Don't throw in the towel yet."
translation.ko: '패배주의자가 되지 마십시오 아직 항복해선 안 됩니다'

translation.en: [narrator] But Reynaud tells Churchill that the situation is hopeless,
and warns that his cabinet colleagues wish to start peace talks with Hitler.
translation.ko: 내각에서는 히틀러와 평화 회담을 시작하기 원한다고 경고한다

translation.en: With Hitler's men gaining ground,
the British Expeditionary Force are retreating towards the coast in droves.
translation.ko: 영국 원정군은 해안을 향해 떼를 지어 후퇴한다

translation.en: It's a race against time for the Germans.
They have the cream of the Allied armies in a trap,
translation.ko: 연합군의 핵심 전력을 독에 든 쥐 신세로 만듭니다

translation.en: and they're not gonna let them out of that trap.
[Roman Toeppel] So they really felt like,
"We will destroy the British and the French Army here on the beach,
and we will have won a decisive victory
translation.ko: '불과 몇 년 전엔 꿈도 꾸지 못한'

translation.en: we couldn't even dream of a couple of years ago."
[narrator] As thousands of Allied troops rush toward safety,
translation.ko: 수천 명의 연합군이 안전한 곳을 찾아 달려갈 때

translation.en: thousands of others are ordered to block the German advance on Dunkirk
translation.ko: 다른 수천 명의 병력은 됭케르크로 진격하는 독일군을 막기 위해

translation.en: by defending key positions such as Calais.
translation.ko: 칼레 같은 요충지를 방어하라는 명령을 받는다

translation.en: Every hour that they managed to save, um, at Calais
was invaluable up at Dunkirk.
[narrator] Commanding the Allied troops is 41-year-old Brigadier Claude Nicholson.
Churchill sent a telegram to, uh, Nicholson in Calais saying that,
translation.ko: 처칠은 칼레에 있는 니컬슨에게 전문을 보내

translation.en: "The eyes of the Empire are upon you."
To have that sent to you when you're a commander,
really, it meant that you just could not surrender.
[narrator] Three days of brutal fighting takes place
between Hitler's Panzer Divisions and the Allies,
who are outnumbered three to one.
Churchill does have the opportunity to evacuate,
but he says, "No, I want you to hold out and keep fighting."
translation.ko: 안 된다고 버티며 계속 싸우라고 하죠

translation.en: It was one of the most difficult decisions
that Winston Churchill had to take in the whole war.
He said it made him physically sick to have to give the order.
translation.ko: 그런 명령을 내려야 해서 몸이 아플 정도라고 했지만

translation.en: But nonetheless, um, he gave it.
It was an example of his leadership.
The outcome for Brigadier Nicholson and his soldiers
was that, uh, none of them get away.
They are either killed, wounded, or captured.
[narrator] After surrendering, Nicholson is sent to a P.O.W. camp in Northern Germany.
translation.ko: 항복한 뒤 니컬슨은 독일 북부 포로수용소로 보내진다

translation.en: And the really sad thing about him is that he ended up committing suicide,
uh, when he was in captivity.
And it seems as though he felt he had let the country down.
translation.ko: 조국에 실망을 줬다고 생각한 것 같은데

translation.en: And yet if you look at the situation, if you look at what he did, he-- he was a hero.
translation.ko: 당시 상황과 그의 행적을 보면 그는 영웅이었습니다

translation.en: [narrator] After returning from France,
Churchill meets with his War Cabinet in London.
Strongly opposed to the war against Germany is Foreign Secretary Lord Halifax,
translation.ko: 독일과의 전쟁을 강력히 반대하는 외무 장관 핼리팩스 경은

translation.en: who wants Churchill to explore peace terms with Hitler.
translation.ko: 처칠이 히틀러와 평화 협정을 맺기 원한다

translation.en: Lord Halifax is popular among his peers in the House of Lords.
translation.ko: 핼리팩스 경은 상원 의원들 사이에서 인기가 있죠

translation.en: He has many supporters in the Tory party.
And another admirer is King George VI.
Halifax is actually not only his party's first choice to be prime minister,
translation.ko: 핼리팩스는 사실 토리당뿐 아니라 국왕도 가장 먼저

translation.en: but also the king's.
He decides that he's not up to the job,
translation.ko: 자신은 수상직을 감당할 수 없을 거라 판단해

translation.en: and therefore, he stands aside.
[narrator] Whilst Halifax believes that Hitler will only want
a few British territories if peace is brokered,
translation.ko: 히틀러가 영국 영토의 일부만 원할 것이라 믿지만

translation.en: Churchill fears Hitler will demand control of the Royal Navy and much more.
translation.ko: 처칠은 히틀러가 해군 통수권과 그 이상을 요구할 거라 우려한다

translation.en: The War Cabinet in the UK is hopelessly split,
and the reason it's split is because there are people in it, uh,
like Halifax who were great realists
and think, "Well, the war can't be won. We need to start negotiations."
translation.ko: 이길 수 없는 전쟁이니 협상을 시작해야 한다고 여겼기 때문이죠

translation.en: And there were also diehards, of course, like Churchill,
who feel we've got to keep fighting till the end, and if we don't, uh,
translation.ko: 끝까지 싸워야 한다고 생각했죠 싸우지 않으면

translation.en: what we'll get out of this will be worse than if we keep going.
translation.ko: 전쟁을 지속하는 것보다 더 나쁜 결과가 나올 거라고요

translation.en: [narrator] On the 25th of May, with no authorization from the War Cabinet,
Halifax meets the Italian Ambassador at the Foreign Office
and asks whether Italy might mediate a ceasefire with Germany.
translation.ko: 이탈리아가 독일과의 휴전을 중재할 수 있을지 묻는다

translation.en: Halifax is not alone in thinking this is the best course of action.
translation.ko: 이를 최선책이라고 생각한 사람은 핼리팩스만이 아니다

translation.en: Joseph Kennedy, JFK's father,
translation.ko: 존 F. 케네디의 아버지인 조지프 케네디

translation.en: is US Ambassador to Britain.
He, too, believes that Britain is finished,
and has tried to sound out the German Ambassador about peace talks.
translation.ko: 독일 대사에게 평화 회담 의사를 타진한다

translation.en: Like Halifax, Kennedy has no government authorization to do this.
It's hard to believe what Churchill was up against at this time.
translation.ko: 이 당시 처칠이 처한 상황은 믿기 어려울 정도죠

translation.en: Not only does he have the challenge from the Germans trying to destroy the BEF,
he also has the enemy within trying to encourage him to negotiate peace.
translation.ko: 평화 협상을 부추기는 내부의 적도 있어요

translation.en: [narrator] Around the same time that Halifax and Kennedy are exploring
translation.ko: 핼리팩스와 케네디가 승인도 없이 평화 회담을

translation.en: illegitimate peace talks,
Churchill decides that British soldiers can no longer fight on in France.
translation.ko: 처칠은 영국 군인들이 더는 프랑스에서 싸워서는 안 된다고

translation.en: They must be evacuated.
The British haven't really got any choice.
It's either throw themselves back across the Channel back to Britain in safety,
or put their hands up in the air and become prisoners of war.
translation.ko: 양손을 들고 전쟁 포로가 되거나 둘 중 하나죠

translation.en: [Roberts] If the British Expeditionary Force were not brought back,
they would either be captured or slaughtered,
and, uh, Churchill understood that you simply couldn't allow
a quarter of a million men to fall into German hands.
translation.ko: 독일군 손에 넘길 수는 없다는 걸 알았죠

translation.en: That would essentially be the end of the war.
[narrator] With the Germans dangerously close
to trapping the British Expeditionary Force,
Churchill calls upon a trusted ally to oversee the rescue operation,
translation.ko: 처칠은 믿을 만한 협력자에게 구출 작전을 주관할 것을 요청한다

translation.en: Vice Admiral Bertram Ramsay.
Churchill knew Ramsay to be an extremely calm commander,
translation.ko: 처칠은 램지가 대단히 침착한 지휘관인 걸 알았고

translation.en: which, of course, was going to be tremendously important in this operation.
translation.ko: 물론 이 작전에는 그 사실이 엄청나게 중요했죠

translation.en: He knew that he was going to be able to get the job done.
translation.ko: 그가 임무를 완수할 수 있으리라는 걸 알았어요

translation.en: [narrator] From offices situated deep in the tunnels beneath Dover Castle,
translation.ko: 도버성 지하 터널 깊숙이 위치한 지휘소에서

translation.en: Ramsay and his team begin planning the evacuation,
translation.ko: 램지와 그의 팀은 철수 계획을 세우기 시작한다

translation.en: code-named Operation Dynamo.
When Ramsay is looking at how to get the British Expeditionary Force away,
translation.ko: 램지가 영국 원정군을 탈출시킬 방법을 찾고 있을 때

translation.en: well, initially, he can see these three large ports,
translation.ko: 맨 처음 눈에 띈 것은 3개의 큰 항구입니다

translation.en: Boulogne, Calais, Dunkirk, so that's how it's going to be done.
translation.ko: 불로뉴, 칼레, 됭케르크 그 항구를 통할 작정이었죠

translation.en: [narrator] Within days,
the German Air Force annihilate the ports of Boulogne and Calais.
translation.ko: 며칠 만에 독일 공군은 불로뉴와 칼레 항구를 파괴한다

translation.en: Through a process of elimination, Boulogne, Calais lost,
translation.ko: 소거 과정을 거쳐 불로뉴와 칼레는 사라지고

translation.en: it becomes only Dunkirk that can be used,
so there really was no choice in the matter.
And bear in mind that Dunkirk was a big,
translation.ko: 염두에 두셔야 할 게 됭케르크는 크고

translation.en: uh, a-- a very busy port.
So, you know, there-- there was a lot of scope
for evacuating the British Expeditionary Force
from such an active port.
[narrator] Situated near the border of France and Belgium,
and 40 miles from the English coast,
Ramsay instructs a large fleet of Royal Navy ships,
ranging from destroyers to gunboats,
to prepare to head for Dunkirk.
By now, over 300,000 Allied soldiers
are fleeing towards the beach, hoping to be rescued.
translation.ko: 구출되기를 희망하며 해변을 향해 도망치고 있다

translation.en: But with the Germans quickly closing in, the clock is ticking.
translation.ko: 그러나 독일군은 빠르게 접근하고 시간은 촉박하다

translation.en: I mean, the expectation is that they've probably got 48 hours at most
before the Germans completely cut them off.
And in 48 hours, the expectation is
if they're lucky, they'll manage to get 45,000 men away.
So, these were best-case scenarios.
This is the largest, uh, coastal evacuation, uh,
you know, in history, up to this point.
It must've looked almost impossible that they were gonna pull it off.
[narrator] With just 48 hours to go, the Royal Navy ships get straight to work.
translation.ko: 불과 48시간을 남겨두고 영국 해군 함선들이 출항한다

translation.en: But by the following evening,
only seven and a half thousand men have been rescued.
translation.ko: 하지만 이튿날 저녁까지 구출된 병사는 고작 7,500명

translation.en: It's very slow, because you've got to decamp the soldiers
translation.ko: 몹시 더뎠죠, 참을성 있게 해안에 줄지어 기다리던

translation.en: who were waiting patiently on the beach in lines.
There can't be panic. They can't all rush the boat.
translation.ko: 허둥댈 수도 배를 재촉할 수도 없어요

translation.en: Well, when you have some few hundred thousand people
crowding on to the beach, it's a scramble.
It's incredibly difficult just simply physically getting toward the water,
translation.ko: 물을 향해 나아가는 것조차 엄청나게 어려워요

translation.en: let alone getting onto a boat.
translation.ko: 배에 타는 건 말할 것도 없고요

translation.en: And they are sitting ducks. It must've been utterly terrifying.
translation.ko: 게다가 손쉬운 목표물이죠 정말 두려웠을 겁니다

translation.en: [narrator] Hitler's Panzers are now within a matter of miles of Dunkirk,
translation.ko: 히틀러의 기갑 부대는 됭케르크를 불과 몇 킬로미터 남겨두고

translation.en: when they receive extraordinary news from German High Command.
translation.ko: 독일 최고 사령부로부터 놀라운 소식을 듣는다

translation.en: An order goes out to halt the Panzers.
And at the front, they're all absolutely spitting about this.
Like, "We're just crossing the canal. You can't make us halt now."
translation.ko: '막 운하를 건너는 참인데 지금 그냥 멈추라니!'

translation.en: [narrator] One of the first to receive the news
translation.ko: 그 소식을 가장 먼저 접한 사람은

translation.en: is Heinz Guderian.
Guderian was rushing towards the Channel.
And then he gets an order to say the Panzer attack has to stop, and he's really furious.
translation.ko: 기갑 부대의 공격을 멈추라는 명령을 받고 정말 분노합니다

translation.en: When you're going forward attacking and you see the enemy's fleeing,
translation.ko: 공격해 나아가는 중에 적이 도망치는 걸 보면

translation.en: then you get some-- some rush of enthusiasm.
And when an-- an order, uh, arrives that you should stop,
you don't understand why.
[David] One of the reasons the halt order is put in place
translation.ko: 중단 명령이 내려진 이유 중 하나는

translation.en: is to allow the infantry who've been lagging behind the armor to catch up.
translation.ko: 기갑 사단에 뒤처진 보병대가 따라잡도록 하기 위해서입니다

translation.en: They were thinking, we've got another battle to fight
against the re-- remaining French armies,
and we need to keep as many of our Panzers intact as possible.
translation.ko: 최대한 많은 기갑 부대를 유지해야 한다고 생각했죠

translation.en: [narrator] But one man sees a golden opportunity in the halt order.
translation.ko: 하지만 이 중단 명령을 절호의 기회로 본 사람이 있다

translation.en: Former World War One fighter ace
and Luftwaffe commander in chief, Hermann Göring.
Göring was maybe the most illustrious of the Nazi leaders.
translation.ko: 괴링은 나치 지도자 중 가장 저명한 인물이었을 겁니다

translation.en: I mean, Hitler completely trusted him.
They were close, old party comrades.
Göring was pompous, jovial, cruel.
He very clearly loved to eat, everybody could tell that.
translation.ko: 먹는 걸 아주 좋아했어요 모두가 다 아는 사실이었죠

translation.en: [narrator] Göring's indulgences do not stop with food.
In 1923, after receiving a bullet wound to the leg
during a failed coup by the Nazis,
Göring became increasingly addicted to morphine.
So much so that Hitler's right-hand man
has twice been admitted to a psychiatric hospital.
And his, um, addictions, uh,
definitely made him more and more prone
to overestimate the abilities of the German Air Force
and to make, uh, grandiose, uh, promises
that he could not keep.
So when this halt order comes up, he goes to Hitler's headquarters.
translation.ko: 중단 명령이 떨어지자 그는 히틀러의 사령부로 가서

translation.en: He goes, "Don't need to worry about that. My Luftwaffe will destroy the British."
translation.ko: 걱정할 것 없다고, 루프트바페가 영국군을 무너뜨리겠다고 해요

translation.en: And Göring says, "Look, Führer, we can bomb the beaches,
translation.ko: 괴링은 말합니다, '총통 각하 해안에 폭격을 가하면 됩니다'

translation.en: we can bomb any ships the British send over to evacuate."
translation.ko: '철수를 위해 보낸 영국 선박에 폭격을 가하면 됩니다'

translation.en: "I can handle this."
[narrator] As thousands of British and French soldiers
are trying to escape across the Channel,
Göring's Luftwaffe start to obliterate the port.
translation.ko: 괴링이 이끄는 루프트바페는 항구를 파괴하기 시작한다

translation.en: Dunkirk was absolutely in disarray.
I mean, it'd been bombed heavily, port was on fire and destroyed,
translation.ko: 격렬한 폭격이 계속되고 항구는 불에 타 파괴되고

translation.en: some dead civilians in the street,
electricity's down, running water's down.
You know, it's a scene of absolute carnage.
[narrator] As wave after wave of German planes reign terror down on the troops,
translation.ko: 독일군 전투기들이 연이어 몰려와 병사들에게 공포를 퍼붓자

translation.en: a cry goes up.
"Where was the RAF?" They were constantly saying, "Where's the RAF?"
translation.ko: '영국 공군은?' 계속 말했죠 '영국 공군은 어디 있지?'

translation.en: There's a lot of controversy about the role of the RAF at Dunkirk,
translation.ko: 됭케르크에서 영국 공군의 역할에 대해 논란이 많았습니다

translation.en: because, you know, the Germans basically had command of the air over the beaches,
and where was the RAF?
So this whole myth grows up that the RAF was absent.
translation.ko: 그래서 영국 공군의 부재에 대한 괴담이 커집니다

translation.en: [Richie] The troops were trapped on the beach. They were frightened.
translation.ko: 병사들은 해변에 갇힌 채 겁에 질려 있었어요

translation.en: They were being strafed by the Luftwaffe,
and they didn't know if they were not gonna be shot or taken prisoner
translation.ko: 앞으로 24시간 안에 총에 맞게 될지, 포로가 될지

translation.en: within the next, uh, 24 hours.
So there was a lot of seething resentment and a lot of rumor,
and people really didn't know what was happening.
translation.ko: 사람들은 어떤 일이 벌어지고 있는지 몰랐어요

translation.en: [narrator] As resentment grows amongst the troops towards the RAF,
translation.ko: 영국 공군을 향한 병사들의 분노가 커지면서

translation.en: so too does their desperation to get home.
But with Dunkirk's port completely destroyed,
the Allies are stranded.
Problem you've got if you're on the beach is how you get from the sand to a boat.
translation.ko: 해변에서는 모래사장에서 배로 이동 방법이 문제가 됩니다

translation.en: And, you know, big ships, which is what's really gonna take the numbers back to Britain,
you know, they can't-- they can't berth onto the sand.
It meant that the British had to think of new ways
translation.ko: 영국군은 배가 됭케르크로 들어갈 새 방법을 생각해

translation.en: to get ships into Dunkirk to pull those troops out.
[narrator] With no simple way of getting off the beaches,
translation.ko: 해안을 탈출할 간단한 방법이 요원한 연합군은

translation.en: the Allies are facing imminent capture or death
translation.ko: 곧 나치의 손에 잡히거나 죽을 상황에

translation.en: at the hands of the Nazis.
From his office deep beneath Dover Castle,
Ramsay knows he's running out of time to get the troops home.
translation.ko: 램지는 병사들을 데려올 시간이 촉박하다는 것을 깨닫는다

translation.en: Desperate for a lifeline, the Navy makes an urgent appeal.
translation.ko: 구명줄이 절실한 해군은 긴급히 도움을 호소한다

translation.en: The Royal Navy got the message out by using various different methods.
translation.ko: 영국 해군은 다양한 방법으로 메시지를 전달했습니다

translation.en: It used newsreels and cinemas,
it used radio broadcast on the BBC,
and they also actually began to phone around the various shipyards.
translation.ko: 실제로 여러 조선소에 전화도 걸기 시작했어요

translation.en: The specific detail of what they wanted was really quite brief.
They were asking for motor yachts at least 30 feet in length,
translation.ko: 모터가 달린 길이 10m 이상의 요트를 구하고 있으니

translation.en: and if you had one of those, you were to report to the admiralty.
All kinds of small ships ended up in Dunkirk.
translation.ko: 온갖 종류의 소형 선박이 됭케르크로 모였어요

translation.en: You had-- You had motor launches,
you had yachts, you had sailing boats,
you had fishing boats.
But the fact was that anything that could be pressed into service
was pressed into service, and they were all needed.
[narrator] One ship owner bound for Dunkirk is Charles Lightoller.
translation.ko: 됭케르크로 향한 선주 중에는 찰스 라이톨러가 있다

translation.en: [Levine] Charles Lightoller had been the senior surviving officer onboard Titanic.
And then during the First World War he'd been a Royal Navy commander.
translation.ko: 세계 1차 대전 때는 영국 해군 지휘관이어서

translation.en: So he'd already had a-- a pretty dramatic life.
[narrator] Lightoller owns a motor yacht named the Sundowner,
recently requisitioned by the Navy
and due to be sailed to Dunkirk by Royal Navy crew.
translation.ko: 영국 해군이 됭케르크로 몰고 갈 예정이었다

translation.en: He wasn't having that. He was going to take Sundowner himself.
translation.ko: 그는 그럴 생각이 없었죠 직접 선다우너를 몰고 가려고요

translation.en: If it was going to be done, he was going to do it.
translation.ko: 가게 될 거라면 자신이 몰고 가려고 했어요

translation.en: So he got together one of his sons, uh, and a sea scout,
translation.ko: 그는 아들 중 하나와 해양 스카우트 단원 한 명을 모아

translation.en: and the three of them went across on this little motor launch.
translation.ko: 그 세 사람이 이 작은 발동선을 타고 건너갔어요

translation.en: [narrator] As Sundowner rushes towards Dunkirk
translation.ko: 선다우너가 수백 척의 작은 배와 함께

translation.en: along with hundreds of other little ships,
Göring's Luftwaffe refuses to give up.
For the troops trapped on the beaches,
resentment towards the seemingly absent RAF is growing.
translation.ko: 보이지 않는 영국 공군에 대한 분노가 커지고 있었다

translation.en: [David] The problem is that a lot of people at Dunkirk didn't see them.
translation.ko: 문제는 됭케르크의 많은 병사는 그들을 못 봤다는 겁니다

translation.en: And if they didn't witness them, they didn't believe they were there
and they didn't believe that they'd done the job they needed to do.
[narrator] Little do the troops know that high above the beaches,
translation.ko: 해변 상공 높은 곳에서 강력한 루프트바페에 맞서

translation.en: the RAF are battling hard against the mighty Luftwaffe.
translation.ko: 영국 공군이 벌인 치열한 전투를 병사들은 거의 알지 못한다

translation.en: On the first day alone, over 250 sorties are flown over the port.
The reason they weren't always seen is because they were either above the cloud cover
translation.ko: 그들이 보이지 않은 건 구름 위에 있었기 때문이에요

translation.en: or, more relevant,
they were actually fighting German fighters away from the actual beachhead.
translation.ko: 실제 해안 해두보에서 멀리 떨어져 독일 전투기와 교전했기 때문이죠

translation.en: The trick for the RAF is to keep the Germans away from Dunkirk,
translation.ko: 영국 공군의 전략은 실제 전장에서 싸우는 게 아니라

translation.en: not to fight them over the actual battlefield.
The perception that the RAF didn't do anything is really unfair,
translation.ko: 영국 공군이 아무것도 하지 않았다는 인식은 부당하고

translation.en: uh, and incorrect as well.
And, of course, with hindsight and with much more historical knowledge,
translation.ko: 물론 뒤늦은 깨달음과 더 많은 역사적 지식을 바탕으로

translation.en: now we know how much they were really doing.
translation.ko: 이제는 그들이 정말로 얼마나 많은 일을 했는지 알죠

translation.en: [narrator] Over the course of the evacuation,
the RAF manages to down up to 240 enemy aircraft,
losing 106 fighter planes of their own.
The battle of France saw 1,500 airmen
captured, wounded, or killed.
But those on the beaches know nothing of this.
translation.ko: 해변에 있는 이들은 아무것도 알지 못한다

translation.en: Soldiers on the beach started to take their anger out
on those few RAF pilots or airmen
translation.ko: 그들과 마찬가지로 귀향하기 위해 해변에 있던

translation.en: who were on the beach also trying to get home.
translation.ko: 몇 안 되는 영국 공군 조종사와 항공병들에게요

translation.en: [Holland] Well, you can imagine, if you're on the-- on the beaches
translation.ko: 상상해 보세요 당신이 그 해안에 있는데

translation.en: and you're absolutely exhausted, you've been defeated,
you've finally got onto a boat, and there you see an RAF pilot.
translation.ko: 간신히 배에 올라탔더니 영국 공군 조종사가 있어요

translation.en: You just think, "Hang on, I thought you were supposed to protect me."
translation.ko: 이런 생각이 들죠 '너희가 날 지켜줄 줄 알았는데'

translation.en: "You're shot down, and there aren't enough of you." "What is going on?"
translation.ko: '격추됐네, 몇 명 되지도 않잖아 대체 뭐야?'

translation.en: So a lot of the RAF pilots got a lot of grief for this.
translation.ko: 상당수의 영국 공군 조종사가 이 일로 비탄에 빠집니다

translation.en: [narrator] RAF pilot and Squadron Commander Anthony Bartley
translation.ko: 영국 공군 조종사이자 비행 중대 지휘관 앤서니 바틀리는

translation.en: recalls the challenges he and his fellow pilots faced.
translation.ko: 자신과 동료 조종사들이 마주쳤던 어려움을 이렇게 회상한다

translation.en: [Bartley] The British soldiers were very antagonistic towards the Air Force.
In fact, a fighter pilot that I knew,
he was shot down at Dunkirk into the sea,
and he swam out to a boat,
translation.ko: 됭케르크에서 격추돼 바다로 떨어졌는데 헤엄쳐서 배에 이르자

translation.en: and a Navy chap said, "Get back. We're not picking up you bastards."
translation.ko: 한 해군 병사가 말했어요 '돌아가, 너희는 안 태워'

translation.en: [chuckling] "We're only picking up the soldiers."
Oh, there was a lot of antagonism.
[narrator] Meanwhile, by the 27th of May,
thousands more men have crowded onto the beaches,
translation.ko: 수천 명의 군인이 더 해변으로 몰려들어

translation.en: desperate to get home.
Despite reinforcements from the little ships,
it's becoming clear to Ramsay that evacuating from the beaches alone
won't be enough to save all the troops.
translation.ko: 모든 병력을 구할 수 없다는 것이 명확해진다

translation.en: [Holland] You've got hundreds of thousands of men on the beaches,
and the smaller the craft,
the, kind of, fewer the number of people you can actually shuffle
translation.ko: 해안에서 다른 배로 실어 나를 수 있는 인원이

translation.en: from one beach to another ship.
And then what you want to be doing is on bulk, en masse.
And little ships, by their very nature, don't allow you to do that.
translation.ko: 작은 배로는 애초에 그렇게 할 수 없죠

translation.en: [Levine] This is a huge undertaking.
Ramsay is trying to rescue an army
from the clutches of its enemy.
And how is he trying to do it? With anything he has.
Whether they are large naval ships,
large civilian ships, small little--
Anything will do, anything can help.
So it's makeshift, it's ad hoc, but it's really, really difficult.
translation.ko: 임시변통이죠, 임시방편요 그러나 정말 어려운 일이죠

translation.en: [narrator] On the same day, Ramsay's equivalent in Dunkirk,
translation.ko: 같은 날, 램지와 같은 계급의 됭케르크 지휘관

translation.en: Senior Naval Officer Bill Tennant arrives to help speed up the evacuation.
translation.ko: 해군 고위 장교 빌 테넌트가 신속한 철수를 돕기 위해 도착한다

translation.en: [Holland] There's already wrecked ships. There's sort of, you know, Stukas diving down.
translation.ko: 이미 난파된 함선도 있고 독일 폭격기는 급강하하고 있죠

translation.en: I mean, it's almost kind of apocalyptic, really, the scene that greets him.
translation.ko: 그를 맞이한 광경은 마치 세상의 종말 같아요

translation.en: [narrator] To make matters worse for Tennant and the troops,
British High Command have just received word
that Hitler has lifted the controversial halt order.
translation.ko: 논란이 많던 중단 명령을 해제했다는 소식이 도착한다

translation.en: The Nazis' dreaded Panzer Divisions are once again racing towards Dunkirk.
translation.ko: 나치의 무시무시한 기갑 사단이 다시 됭케르크를 향해 질주한다

translation.en: With a destroyed port, thousands of men waiting to be rescued,
translation.ko: 파괴된 항구와 구조를 기다리는 수천 명의 병사

translation.en: and the threat of the Nazis, both in the sky and on the ground,
translation.ko: 하늘과 육지 양측에서 이어지는 나치의 위협 속에

translation.en: for Tennant, the prospect of evacuating 45,000 men in just two days
seems impossible.
This is all going so slowly, so slowly. Something has to be done.
translation.ko: 모든 게 너무 느려요 뭔가 해야 합니다

translation.en: And he has to think quickly, act quickly.
[narrator] Tennant spots a glimmer of hope.
What he notices is there is this mole, this sort of breakwater
translation.ko: 그의 눈에 띈 건 방죽 일종의 방파제입니다

translation.en: that extends kind of a mile-- a mile plus out into the sea.
[David] It's really to protect a harbor.
You're not supposed to use it as a means of getting on ships.
translation.ko: 배를 타는 수단으로 쓰는 것은 아니지만

translation.en: But, of course, it's needs must at Dunkirk.
So he thinks, "All right, let's try and use it as a jetty."
And it worked.
And the reason it's a game changer is because if you can get a big ship
translation.ko: 그걸로 판도가 바뀐 이유는 묄더스나 구축함

translation.en: coming alongside a mole, a destroyer, paddle steamer, or something of that type,
translation.ko: 외차선 같은 큰 배를 댈 수 있으면

translation.en: you can load an awful lot of soldiers onto it relatively quickly.
translation.ko: 상대적으로 빠르게 엄청나게 많은 수의 병사를 태워

translation.en: And far more people escaped from the mole then they did from the beaches.
translation.ko: 해변에서보다 훨씬 더 많은 사람을 탈출시킬 수 있기 때문이죠

translation.en: [narrator] Tennant's discovery of the mole isn't the only example
of ingenuity in action at Dunkirk.
translation.ko: 됭케르크에서 독창성이 발휘된 예는 테넌트 방죽 발견만이 아니다

translation.en: The race to get to the beach is paramount for the soldiers.
translation.ko: 서둘러 해변으로 가는 게 병사들에게는 중요한데

translation.en: And they're encumbered with heavy guns, artillery.
Some of them have trucks, even tanks, and all sorts of other equipment,
translation.ko: 일부에겐 트럭, 심지어 탱크나 온갖 종류의 기타 장비

translation.en: the detritus of war.
And they realize that they're not gonna be able to bring this with them.
translation.ko: 그걸 가져갈 수는 없다는 걸 깨달아요

translation.en: [narrator] Approximately 85,000 vehicles are left behind
by men fleeing for the coast.
But whilst waiting to be rescued,
a group of Royal Engineers come up with a cunning idea.
People could see the big mole at one end,
translation.ko: 한쪽 끝에 큰 방죽이 보이지 않는 사람들은

translation.en: and otherwise, people were just having to queue along the beaches.
translation.ko: 그냥 해변을 따라 줄을 서 있어야 했는데

translation.en: And they thought, "We could build our own jetties and do it using lorries."
Once they burst the tires, they would push them out, uh, in a line.
They would attach them to each other.
They would put sandbags along the top,
and then wooden planking on top of that.
And then they had made themselves a pier.
And-- And so this type of… [inhales] …ingenuity
was one of the ways that people got by at Dunkirk,
and one of the ways that they made things just slightly easier for themselves.
translation.ko: 상황을 조금 개선할 수 있었던 한 방법이었죠

translation.en: [narrator] The number of men evacuated from Dunkirk
has now more than doubled to over 25,000.
We're talking about ten miles of beaches, hundreds of thousands of people.
translation.ko: 길이 16km의 해변에 수십만 명의 사람들이 있으니

translation.en: So every kind of human life was on those beaches.
[Holland] Lots of different people have different experiences of Dunkirk.
translation.ko: 많은 사람이 됭케르크에 대해 서로 다른 경험을 합니다

translation.en: For some, it's just one of absolute chaos.
Some people are getting their head down to get some sleep, they're so exhausted.
translation.ko: 어떤 이들은 머리를 숙이고 자요 너무 지쳤으니까요

translation.en: Other people are raiding the bars and cafés and trying to get some drink.
translation.ko: 다른 이들은 술집과 카페에 난입해 마실 것을 구하려 하는데

translation.en: And very often the water's already been turned off.
The mains has been burst in Dunkirk, so there's no running water.
translation.ko: 됭케르크의 수도관이 터져서 물이 안 나오니까

translation.en: So they're kind of getting drunk on wine, but at least it's fluid.
[Levine] People playing cricket on the beach.
You had a circus performer who was doing tricks
on the back of a horse that he'd found.
Um, one man I spoke to who loved motorcycles found a motorcycle,
translation.ko: 제가 만난 한 남자는 오토바이를 좋아했는데 그걸 발견하고

translation.en: and he was going up and down the beach, just having the time of his life.
People were having fun, people were having a terrible time,
translation.ko: 사람들은 즐기기도 하고 끔찍한 시간을 보내기도 하고

translation.en: people were fighting, people were being orderly, people were being disorderly.
translation.ko: 싸우기도 하고, 질서를 지키기도 무질서하기도 했어요

translation.en: People were being people.
That's what you had on the beaches.
[narrator] As the evacuees wait to be rescued,
in the towns surrounding the port, a battle is raging.
translation.ko: 항구를 둘러싼 마을에서는 전투가 벌어지고 있다

translation.en: Thousands of men are defending the perimeter around Dunkirk.
translation.ko: 수천 명의 병사가 됭케르크 주변을 방어하고 있다

translation.en: Twenty-five miles in length and eight miles deep,
it's made up of a system of canals and waterways,
with the French defending the west and the British in the east.
translation.ko: 서쪽에선 프랑스군이 동쪽에선 영국군이 방어하고 있다

translation.en: The order to these rearguard units is simple,
translation.ko: 이 후방 부대에 내려진 명령은 단순하다

translation.en: fight to the last man.
[David] I think one of the most heroic
and often unrecognized stories of the Dunkirk evacuation
translation.ko: 잘 알려지지 않은 이야기 중 하나는

translation.en: is these last-ditch stands that are happening
all over, uh, the defensive perimeter, uh, around Dunkirk.
Um, we think of the ships, we think of the heroism of the Navy,
translation.ko: 이 최후의 고군분투라고 생각합니다 우리는 배와 해군의 영웅적인 행동을 생각하면서

translation.en: and we often forget that a lot of soldiers sacrificed themselves
translation.ko: 동료 병사들이 도망갈 수 있도록 자신을 희생한

translation.en: so that their fellows could get away.
They were told they were going to be defending this perimeter.
translation.ko: 자신들이 이 지역을 방어할 것이라고 들었어요

translation.en: They said that-- that wave after wave after wave of soldiers came past them,
translation.ko: 군인들이 연이어 몰려와 자신들을 지나쳐 갔다고 했죠

translation.en: but that that was how it was going to be.
They were going to have to sacrifice themselves if it was necessary.
So it was an enormously selfless, um,
and incredibly dangerous job.
[narrator] Back in London, Churchill is watching and waiting
to see how many men of the British Expeditionary Force
translation.ko: 얼마나 많은 영국 원정군을 구출할 수 있을지

translation.en: can be saved.
Meanwhile, his foreign secretary, Lord Halifax,
is still intent on reaching a peace agreement with Hitler.
translation.ko: 여전히 히틀러와의 평화 협정을 맺으려 한다

translation.en: Realizing he needs to put a stop to Halifax's persistence,
Churchill calls for a full cabinet meeting
involving ministers from across all parties.
[David] What he tells the full cabinet
is an unvarnished account of what's happening in France.
translation.ko: 프랑스 상황에 대한 있는 그대로의 사실입니다

translation.en: He makes no bones about the difficulty they're in.
But what he also says is, "What will be the consequences if we give in now?"
translation.ko: 동시에 지금 굴복하면 어떤 결과가 올지를 말해요

translation.en: And that will be Britain is reduced to a slave state.
And I suppose the most dramatic, uh, part of this speech is the final bit where he says,
translation.ko: 이 연설에서 가장 극적인 부분은 마지막입니다

translation.en: "If our island story is to end here,
let it only end when each one of us
translation.ko: '오직 우리가 모두 땅에 쓰러져 자신의 피로'

translation.en: is choking in his own blood, lying on the ground."
The response to this meeting, according to Churchill,
was a huge outbreak of cheering from the other members of the cabinet,
and it was quite clear from this point onwards
that they wanted to continue the fight.
[narrator] It's clear to Halifax
there can be no more secret talks regarding peace with Hitler.
translation.ko: 이젠 히틀러와의 비밀 평화 회담은 없다

translation.en: Instead, Britain needs a miracle.
Over 40,000 men have now been rescued,
thanks in no small part to the weather.
The weather plays a key role in the Dunkirk evacuation.
translation.ko: 됭케르크 철수에 날씨가 중요한 역할을 합니다

translation.en: And at first, it's on the side of the Allies.
So you get a lot of cloud cover, a lot of, uh, difficulty
for the, uh, German Luftwaffe to observe what's going on on the ground.
And while this is happening, an awful lot of soldiers are able to get away.
translation.ko: 그동안 정말 많은 병사가 탈출하게 됩니다

translation.en: I mean, it's tempting to think that it was all ingenuity
translation.ko: 전부 독창성과 여러 방법을 생각한 사람들 덕분에

translation.en: and people working out how to do things that got the British home,
translation.ko: 영국군을 데려올 수 있었다고 생각하기 쉽지만

translation.en: but actually, there was quite a lot of chance involved as well.
[narrator] But during the afternoon, the skies begin to clear.
translation.ko: 그러나 오후가 되자 하늘이 개기 시작한다

translation.en: The RAF defend the area in full force.
But seizing the opportunity of clear skies,
Göring's Luftwaffe begin their most brutal bombing raid
since the start of the evacuation.
So the situation for the British becomes much more dire when the weather clears,
translation.ko: 날이 개면서 영국군의 상황은 훨씬 더 심각해집니다

translation.en: because now you've got the Luftwaffe flying, you know,
pretty much unchecked over the beaches, and strafing and bombing at will.
translation.ko: 해안 상공을 날며 기관총을 쏘고 폭격을 했으니까요

translation.en: The Luftwaffe's very young, very keen, and very national socialists spirit,
and they want to sink ships,
and they want to defeat the enemy as fast as possible.
And they don't really think so much about suffering of the troops
translation.ko: 해안을 공격하면서 그 병사들의 고통에 대해서는

translation.en: when they hit the beach.
[narrator] Casting off from the mole is a Thames paddle steamer named the Crested Eagle.
In peacetime, she was used by day-trippers
visiting seaside resorts along the English coast.
translation.ko: 해변 휴양지를 방문하는 일일 여행객들을 실어 나르다가

translation.en: Then, at the start of the war, to evacuate children.
translation.ko: 전쟁이 시작되자 아이들을 대피시키는 데에 이용됐고

translation.en: At Dunkirk, she is carrying 600 troops back to Britain
when the Luftwaffe Stukas spot her preparing to leave.
translation.ko: 출항 준비를 하다가 루프트바페 스투카에 포착된다

translation.en: [Holland] The very nature of Stukas is that you dive down as close as you can
before you drop your ordnance
so you make yourself more accurate, that's the whole point.
They would dive very nearly vertically,
and they would come out of their dive at something like 1,500 feet.
And they carried one large bomb and two smaller bombs on each wing.
translation.ko: 각 날개에 큰 폭탄 하나와 작은 폭탄 둘을 실었어요

translation.en: -And also, they screamed. -[sirens screaming]
The sirens were added to the Stukas
in order to, um-- to terrorize the troops,
in order to increase the fear of a Stuka attack.
So when they targeted ships on the mole or out to sea,
or even people on the beaches,
translation.ko: 심지어 해안에 있는 사람들을 노렸을 때

translation.en: they could do a hell of a lot of damage.
[narrator] Four bombs hit the Crested Eagle in quick succession,
transforming it into a blazing inferno.
The carnage they caused is-- is indescribable.
Survivors talk about… seeing others who were unrecognizable,
translation.ko: 생존자들은 서로 알아볼 수 없었다고 합니다

translation.en: um, because the-- the damage to their faces was so bad.
People were jumping off, people were, um…
One man managed to get to shore,
and only when he was onshore he realized that his hands were-- were ribbons,
translation.ko: 육지에 도착해서야 자기 손이 띠란 걸 깨달았어요

translation.en: because the skin had just peeled completely away.
[narrator] Approximately 300 men die in the attack.
Even so, the captain is able to run the Crested Eagle aground.
translation.ko: 그래도 선장은 크레스티드 이글을 암초에 댈 수 있었다

translation.en: She's not the only ship to suffer severe losses that day.
translation.ko: 그날 심각한 손상을 입은 배는 그뿐만이 아니다

translation.en: Ten destroyers, eight personnel ships,
and a number of smaller vessels are annihilated.
[David] Can you imagine what it must've been like?
You are on the mole, you've been waiting there for hours,
you've finally got on a ship, you think deliverance is near at hand,
translation.ko: 드디어 배에 타게 되어 곧 구조되겠다고 생각했는데

translation.en: and then boom, your ship is blown to pieces.
[narrator] Desperately trying to leave Dunkirk is Charles Lightoller,
who, along with one of his sons and a sea scout,
translation.ko: 아들과 한 명의 해양 스카우트와 함께

translation.en: is heading for Ramsgate on his ship, the Sundowner.
translation.ko: 자신의 배 선다우너를 타고 램즈케이트로 향한다

translation.en: With them are 130 troops
who they have saved from a burning destroyer.
Bear in mind that Sundowner really only had room for about 20, 25 people.
[narrator] But as Sundowner sets off,
Lightoller spots a dive bomber heading straight for them.
translation.ko: 라이톨러는 그들을 향해 돌진해 오는 폭격기를 발견한다

translation.en: And basically, he used a tactic that his Air Force son had taught him.
translation.ko: 기본적으로 그가 쓴 전술은 공군인 그의 아들에게 배운 거였죠

translation.en: So he kept a very, very close eye on the Stuka,
and every time it came down,
he basically veered to one side violently
so that the bombs would miss.
[narrator] The tactic works.
On the first of June, Lightoller's Sundowner arrives safely
-with all 130 troops onboard. -[triumphant music playing]
He was involved in this extraordinary cat and mouse
between this tiny little boat
and this extraordinary, powerful, deadly aircraft.
translation.ko: 이 대단하고 강력하며 치명적인 비행기 사이에 벌어진 추격전요

translation.en: [narrator] By the evening of the first of June,
of the 41 destroyers sent to Dunkirk,
only nine remain undamaged.
So concerned is senior naval officer Bill Tennant
about the mounting casualties,
that he orders for the remainder of the evacuation to take place at night.
Twenty-four hours later, the last ships carrying the British Expeditionary Force
translation.ko: 24시간 뒤, 영국 원정군을 실은 마지막 배들이

translation.en: begin to leave Dunkirk.
Tennant and a colleague scour the beaches for any remaining troops.
translation.ko: 테넌트와 동료 한 사람은 해안을 뒤지며 남은 병사를 찾는다

translation.en: They go down the whole length of the Dunkirk evacuation beaches
translation.ko: 됭케르크 철수 해변 전체를 따라 내려가며

translation.en: with a megaphone going, "Anyone still there? Anyone still there?"
And when they don't get a single reply,
at 11:30 p.m. that night Bill Tennant signals back to Ramsay,
translation.ko: 밤 11시 30분 빌 테넌트는 램지에게 전신을 보내

translation.en: and he goes, "BEF evacuated."
Every Tom, Dick, and Harry has been lifted.
[narrator] The British have achieved the unthinkable.
translation.ko: 영국은 상상도 못 할 일을 해냈다

translation.en: They had originally expected to rescue 45,000 men,
but by the 4th of June almost 340,000 troops
had been evacuated from Dunkirk,
including over 100,000 French soldiers.
The evacuation has been referred to as the Miracle of Dunkirk with good reason,
translation.ko: '됭케르크의 기적'이라 하는 데는 그럴 만한 이유가 있습니다

translation.en: because it should never have happened, wouldn't have without the halt order.
translation.ko: 공격 중단 명령이 없었다면 절대 불가능했고

translation.en: It wouldn't have happened without the weather turning against the Germans for most of the time.
translation.ko: 날씨가 독일군에게 불리하게 변하지 않았다면 불가능했고

translation.en: It wouldn't have happened, frankly, without the heroism of the Royal Navy and those small ships
translation.ko: 영국 해군과 그 작은 배들의 영웅적인 행동과

translation.en: and those crucial troops holding the perimeter
translation.ko: 방어선을 지키며 타인을 위해 자신을 희생했던

translation.en: and sacrificing themselves for their others.
translation.ko: 그 귀한 군인들이 없이는 불가능했을 겁니다

translation.en: All of those factors had to be pulled off for what was genuinely a miracle.
translation.ko: 진정한 기적이 일어나려면 그 모든 요소가 완성돼야만 했죠

translation.en: [narrator] Back in England, thousands of men begin to arrive home,
translation.ko: 영국에서는 수천 명의 병사가 고국에 도착하기 시작한다

translation.en: unsure of the reception they'll face.
translation.ko: 자신들을 어떻게 받아들일지 확신하지 못한 채

translation.en: They were afraid that they were gonna be met with hostility,
that people were gonna accuse them of having left or run away.
And they were very nervous about it, a lot of them.
A lot of these people, remember, hadn't even fired a shot.
You know, they'd just gone straight into retreat and got back.
They consider themselves remnants of a defeated army.
They-- They thought they had absolutely nothing to be proud of.
[narrator] Lieutenant Ian English recalls coming back to Britain.
translation.ko: 이언 잉글리시 대위는 영국으로의 귀환을 이렇게 회상한다

translation.en: [English] We, uh, were put into a train.
And whenever we stopped, people came up with
coffee and cigarettes and this sort of thing.
translation.ko: 커피와 담배 같은 걸 갖고 왔어요

translation.en: And we have evidence of this tremendous euphoria, really,
translation.ko: 우린 이 엄청난 고양감의 증거를 경험했는데

translation.en: quite unfounded, that, uh…
that we were some sort of heroes and we won some sort of a victory.
translation.ko: 우리는 일종의 영웅이고 일종의 승리를 거두었단 고양감요

translation.en: Amazing, really.
It was obvious, really,
um, that we'd been thoroughly beaten.
And they were astonished to find that they were very often treated as heroes.
translation.ko: 종종 영웅 취급을 받는다는 사실에 그들은 놀랐죠

translation.en: And I think what that
gives an indication of is this sort of birth of Dunkirk spirit.
I think it was something that rose absolutely organically
out of, first of all, relief that brothers and uncles and fathers
translation.ko: 무엇보다도 안도감에서요 형제와 삼촌과 아버지와 아들이

translation.en: and sons were home and they were safe,
but also relief at the fact
that the country was still fighting, the country was still in the war.
translation.ko: 여전히 싸우고 있다는 여전히 전쟁 중이라는 안도감

translation.en: It hadn't been defeated.
[Churchill] We must be very careful not to assign to this deliverance
translation.ko: 우리는 이 구출을 승리로 여기지 않도록

translation.en: the attributes of a victory.
Wars are not won by evacuation.
We shall go on to the end.
We shall fight in France.
We shall fight on the seas and oceans.
We'll fight on the beaches.
We shall fight in the fields and in the streets.
We shall never surrender.
Winston Churchill, in this speech, was entirely leveling with the British people.
translation.ko: 이 연설 내내 윈스턴 처칠은 영국 국민에게 진솔했습니다

translation.en: He was not going to try to spin Dunkirk out into a victory.
He knew it wasn't, they knew it wasn't.
translation.ko: 그렇지 않다는 것은 그도, 국민도 알았죠

translation.en: However, it has an incredibly powerful effect on British morale.
translation.ko: 하지만 영국의 사기에는 엄청난 영향을 끼칩니다

translation.en: It told British people what the government and the High Command were going to do,
translation.ko: 정부와 최고 사령부가 무엇을 할 것인지

translation.en: what was expected of them, of course, as well,
and it did so in language that will live for as long as the English tongue.
translation.ko: 영어가 지속하는 한은 길이 남을 언어로요

translation.en: [narrator] The deliverance of the troops from Dunkirk
changes attitudes at home and abroad.
Anyone who had talked of Britain making terms with Hitler is now an outcast.
translation.ko: 영국과 히틀러의 협상을 말했던 사람은 이제 배제된다

translation.en: Well, Halifax's attempt to encourage the, uh, Cabinet
to begin negotiations ultimately fails.
Um, he, by the end of the year, is sent to America as Ambassador.
translation.ko: 그는 연말이 되자 대사로 미국에 파견됩니다

translation.en: Churchill is quoted as saying about Halifax,
translation.ko: 핼리팩스에 대해 처칠은 이렇게 말했다고 해요

translation.en: "He has no future in this country."
[narrator] Similarly, Joseph Kennedy,
who had hopes of one day becoming president
and believed that Britain could never defeat the Nazis,
translation.ko: 영국은 절대 나치를 물리칠 수 없다고 믿었던 그도

translation.en: becomes increasingly unpopular in his role as Ambassador to Britain.
translation.ko: 영국 주재 대사로서의 인기가 점점 떨어진다

translation.en: By the end of 1940, Kennedy pretty much has no choice but to resign.
translation.ko: 1940년 말이 되자 케네디는 사임할 수밖에 없죠

translation.en: And it's at this point that Kennedy's political career is over.
translation.ko: 이 시점에서 케네디의 정치 경력은 끝났습니다

translation.en: The evacuation of the British Army from Dunkirk is absolutely crucial
translation.ko: 됭케르크에서 영국군의 철수는 연합국이 전쟁에서 승리하는 데에 절대적으로 중요합니다

translation.en: to the eventual Allied success in the war,
translation.ko: 연합국이 전쟁에서 승리하는 데에 절대적으로 중요합니다

translation.en: because, uh, it leaves Britain alive
as, like, the kind of last resisting democracy in Europe to, uh, the Nazi onslaught.
translation.ko: 나치의 맹공에 맞선 유럽 민주주의 마지막 저항 같은 존재로요

translation.en: That Britain remains in the fight buys time
for this big Ally coalition to form
-and ultimately defeat the Axis Powers. -[dramatic music plays]
It just seems to me that-- that the fact
that the British Army got away at Dunkirk
wasn't just a nice little story
that makes us feel nice about being British.
If the British Expeditionary Force hadn't got away at Dunkirk,
translation.ko: 만약 영국 원정군이 됭케르크에서 탈출하지 못했다면

translation.en: if it had been taken prisoner,
if it had-- had been destroyed,
if Britain had gone down at this point,
we would be living in a very, very dark world today.
translation.ko: 우리는 오늘날 몹시 어두운 세상에 살고 있었을 겁니다
